5A27D8F328284E349ABB66295A6D2FC3.description: (A) describe the characteristics of alpha, beta, and gamma radioactive decay processes in terms of balanced nuclear equations; and

E718B0ECF3DF49D2A49445978CDD2B5B.description: (12) Science concepts. The student understands the basic processes of nuclear chemistry. The student is expected to:

CE4A603940344B5A987092E11FDFF38F.description: (D) perform calculations involving heat, mass, temperature change, and specific heat.

87379F69AA4849FA8050D74B1A476706.description: (C) classify reactions as exothermic or endothermic and represent energy changes that occur in chemical reactions using thermochemical equations or graphical analysis; and

1A48FA58423B43238403E1468C00E57B.description: (B) describe the law of conservation of energy and the processes of heat transfer in terms of calorimetry;

7336E036E061491FADB19E68F028AD71.description: (A) describe energy and its forms, including kinetic, potential, chemical, and thermal energies;

8D7A9D558A6D49499D10C8EC9AEF55A1.description: (11) Science concepts. The student understands the energy changes that occur in chemical reactions. The student is expected to:

03187F96590A4DC2916220125FFEB1F1.description: (H) define pH and calculate the pH of a solution using the hydrogen ion concentration.

60AA7569D68747649272BDC6955DFE3A.description: (G) define acids and bases and distinguish between Arrhenius and Bronsted-Lowry definitions and predict products in acid-base reactions that form water; and

9CD89C1BA414427EAE619D71121977DE.description: (F) investigate factors that influence solid and gas solubilities and rates of dissolution such as temperature, agitation, and surface area;

EC4BB5A6E66C47168B19A4F458E7C7AE.description: (E) distinguish among types of solutions such as electrolytes and nonelectrolytes; unsaturated, saturated, and supersaturated solutions; and strong and weak acids and bases;

ADC07906F82446B7875287DDC412C6B3.description: (D) calculate the dilutions of solutions using molarity;

C8EA18A90BCD4DEEBFDFFB085A963FF9.description: (C) calculate the concentration of solutions in units of molarity;

6DDF981563A248029E64F4C1180DCAD2.description: (B) apply the general rules regarding solubility through investigations with aqueous solutions;

6154488EA7BB41D0BDC54D784BC763C8.description: (A) describe the unique role of water in solutions in terms of polarity;

9A69AEE73E284719BA3F88FFAE7D92F4.description: (10) Science concepts. The student understands and can apply the factors that influence the behavior of solutions. The student is expected to:

3EF06FC6F1D548A1B6666CE30F4C25C2.description: (B) describe the postulates of kinetic molecular theory.

16C8B4A665E0497D8EA3CDD541251668.description: (A) describe and calculate the relations between volume, pressure, number of moles, and temperature for an ideal gas as described by Boyle's law, Charles' law, Avogadro's law, Dalton's law of partial pressure, and the ideal gas law; and

A772F59FCEDF41AEA68BACE3C9C5110C.description: (9) Science concepts. The student understands the principles of ideal gas behavior, kinetic molecular theory, and the conditions that influence the behavior of gases. The student is expected to:

9C5CDF40E9D14A679777B9E1AC04F3B7.description: (H) describe the concept of limiting reactants in a balanced chemical equation.

CCD1D7D703294B46AC26835A00AF2735.description: (G) perform stoichiometric calculations, including determination of mass and gas volume relationships between reactants and products and percent yield; and

8C6B099111C642DE86FE8FDCBA9A02C8.description: (F) differentiate among double replacement reactions, including acid-base reactions and precipitation reactions, and oxidation-reduction reactions such as synthesis, decomposition, single replacement, and combustion reactions;

561D558DF83C432E85266CD9FAE42E17.description: (E) write and balance chemical equations using the law of conservation of mass;

DCBF4B36B12F4E3A9793DA888B8D9645.description: (D) differentiate between empirical and molecular formulas;

612EE60EBEAC4F13BD5EA45D58E73BF7.description: (B) calculate the number of atoms or molecules in a sample of material using Avogadro's number;

B15505C52F5541C189F660A693B3F841.description: (A) define and use the concept of a mole;

3DA13A10C4D740228EFF99C15536681E.description: (8) Science concepts. The student can quantify the changes that occur during chemical reactions. The student is expected to:

7FDF4550C56940B0B128F42A997465AF.description: (E) classify molecular structure for molecules with linear, trigonal planar, and tetrahedral electron pair geometries as explained by Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR) theory.

81F768CB7BD9458CB7244203213397A5.description: (D) describe metallic bonding and explain metallic properties such as thermal and electrical conductivity, malleability, and ductility; and

BE187CCF1AF845ACBBEBA4A79FD9254D.description: (C) construct electron dot formulas to illustrate ionic and covalent bonds;

1D0FF91CB5AE4C8FAA7742CE2D67F081.description: (B) write the chemical formulas of ionic compounds containing representative elements, transition metals and common polyatomic ions, covalent compounds, and acids and bases;

D9926C0B6E2F4A1FB1BBB69E412F9B2E.description: (A) name ionic compounds containing main group or transition metals, covalent compounds, acids, and bases using International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature rules;

F8ECA57906F440FB913DB825633B5B42.description: (7) Science concepts. The student knows how atoms form ionic, covalent, and metallic bonds. The student is expected to:

580CDF949A53414784BFD644F650D3B0.description: (D) express the arrangement of electrons in atoms of representative elements using electron configurations and Lewis valence electron dot structures.

1E352938C36D4482ACCDC57B50653180.description: (C) calculate average atomic mass of an element using isotopic composition; and

C4E0CAA358AC425090C2FEA4C475AE35.description: (B) describe the mathematical relationships between energy, frequency, and wavelength of light using the electromagnetic spectrum;

2032602AC3664C858BC9F92911B389D4.description: (A) describe the experimental design and conclusions used in the development of modern atomic theory, including Dalton's Postulates, Thomson's discovery of electron properties, Rutherford's nuclear atom, and Bohr's nuclear atom;

6EDE94F7EDDD49108FBF15B760D82C67.description: (6) Science concepts. The student knows and understands the historical development of atomic theory. The student is expected to:

DF01765AE28341EF9F5D201F5B52D69E.description: (C) interpret periodic trends, including atomic radius, electronegativity, and ionization energy, using the Periodic Table.

01E19FEF3F1B4F8E88244BE5915D1788.description: (B) identify and explain the properties of chemical families, including alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, halogens, noble gases, and transition metals, using the Periodic Table; and

76FD1226704A4D43BAF2193959695FC9.description: (A) explain the use of chemical and physical properties in the historical development of the Periodic Table;

9B602B6783D249C0BF5388508F2B0A5A.description: (5) Science concepts. The student understands the historical development of the Periodic Table and can apply its predictive power. The student is expected to:

56660242638744748FFD6BB85D99D943.description: (D) classify matter as pure substances or mixtures through investigation of their properties.

52C4126DE89E4EC2A37D8B76C8E5DC29.description: (C) compare solids, liquids, and gases in terms of compressibility, structure, shape, and volume; and

9A0B0E08764C4226B5F4F8866B7397FE.description: (B) identify extensive properties such as mass and volume and intensive properties such as density and melting point;

9ECD1E1A2DDD4B7595ADB57748A0738F.description: (A) differentiate between physical and chemical changes and properties;

A90DC187CB604D2297163520CD47893D.description: (4) Science concepts. The student knows the characteristics of matter and can analyze the relationships between chemical and physical changes and properties. The student is expected to:

9823FA01D2A448D9AEBA71E9837C6CB0.description: (F) describe the history of chemistry and contributions of scientists.

E648F72C0D394760BB88B0782F4B1DFE.description: (E) describe the connection between chemistry and future careers; and

54ABF4191D134A47AED1B6E941AA9BE5.description: (D) evaluate the impact of research on scientific thought, society, and the environment;

35ACE7E15C65403381F4E7B87B0E3D2A.description: (C) draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services;

920409C2B8674F1CA83F63AAA4599A52.description: (B) communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

5127DA5F47CA4C519C16533B6ABF2091.description: (A) analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

227576A1CB9744F6967AD0F90C77173E.description: (3) Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

7D24AB3F7B834374AC225366149E1BDE.description: (I) communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphs, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.

DBBF744C2A5B43C4A9BE337D3BDC77E2.description: (H) organize, analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data; and

639604DF8C6E4772A5E37F9E5C5AF3E6.description: (G) express and manipulate chemical quantities using scientific conventions and mathematical procedures, including dimensional analysis, scientific notation, and significant figures;

40BC28D33D0A44F8BA75B2A5343D308B.description: (F) collect data and make measurements with accuracy and precision;

48E685A5B8E34D1E85FAD344C5F2A496.description: (E) plan and implement investigative procedures, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology, including graphing calculators, computers and probes, electronic balances, an adequate supply of consumable chemicals, and sufficient scientific glassware such as beakers, Erlenmeyer flasks, pipettes, graduated cylinders, volumetric flasks, and burettes;

82EA8866096B4B22B7EED313D04FF060.description: (D) distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories;

5F8440195E804CC3A33C5BCE542454F2.description: (C) know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well established and highly reliable explanations, but may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed;

55D638F98AD94AA0A3183B3EF3DEE888.description: (B) know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories;

2C2A9CFCB1A04B3BA79FA92392674CFC.description: (A) know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(2) of this section;

A1D414CBEFDC43DCAFB5DE45CCA62595.description: (2) Scientific processes. The student uses scientific practices to solve investigative questions. The student is expected to:

F1B4CB7FB4254E4D93D675EE6D9B4FFA.description: (C) demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

BEECCE7E5A5E465EA2116C050935E1D3.description: (B) know specific hazards of chemical substances such as flammability, corrosiveness, and radioactivity as summarized on the Safety Data Sheets (SDS); and

2C46185B253547C0BD4BCE370426AD68.description: (A) demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations, including the appropriate use of safety showers, eyewash fountains, safety goggles or chemical splash goggles, as appropriate, and fire extinguishers;

4FE4F1045EC64917A8664C1E737D063F.description: (1) Scientific processes. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. The student is expected to:
